Award.AwardTitle: Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1308777, Principal Investigator: Mohammad Ghomi

The principal investigator proposes to continue his work on the theory of curves and surfaces in Euclidean space, and more generally on Riemannian submanifolds of low dimension or codimension. He specializes in applying contemporary methods such as curvature flows and h-principle theory to solve classical problems which often have simple intuitive statements, while their solutions may require sophisticated techniques. The PI's research in this area spans a wide range of topics including isometric embeddings, isoperimetric problems, geometric knot theory, polyhedral approximations, and connections with real algebraic geometry. Some recurring themes throughout these investigations are various notions of convexity or optimization, and the interaction between geometric and topological concepts, or local versus global properties of submanifolds. More specifically, a typical problem is how restrictions on curvature, intrinsic metric, or various boundary conditions, influence the global shape of a curve or a hypersurface, or even allow an embedding of that object in a Euclidean space of low codimension. A fundamental problem in this area is that of isometric rigidity of surfaces: can one continuously deform a smooth closed surface in Euclidean space without changing its intrinsic metric? We also consider a number of related problems involving the self-linking number or vertices of closed curves, spherical images of closed surfaces, and various deformations of submanifolds which preserve the sign or magnitude of the curvature. Other projects include inequalities for mean chord lengths of submanifolds, regularity of real algebraic hypersurfaces, and unfoldings of convex polyhedra.

Curves and surfaces are to geometry what numbers are to algebra. They form the basic ingredients of our visual perception and inspire the development of far reaching mathematical tools. Yet despite centuries of pure study, and an abundance of potential applications, there are still many fundamental open problems in this area which are strikingly intuitive and elementary to state. Studying these problems may stimulate useful developments in pure mathematics, or lead to wider applications in science and technology. For instance, the PI's work on rigidity problem for surfaces may have applications for stability of complicated domes in modern architecture, or various physical frameworks. The polyhedral approximation techniques which the PI is proposing could be useful in computer aided design, and the emerging field of discrete differential geometry. The related studies of the Gauss maps of surfaces could be useful in computer vision and optics, while studying isoperimetric problems has been a significant source of enrichment in calculus of variations and mathematical physics. Further, folding-unfolding problems have numerous applications ranging from deployment of satellite dishes in space to implantation of stents in human arteries. Another impact of the proposed activity would be development of connections between various fields, as in the PI's work on tangent cones, which combines concepts from geometric measure theory, algebraic geometry, and convex analysis. Finally, these problems are ideal for introducing the general public to the exciting world of modern day mathematics, and arousing the interest of beginning students in Geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the inception of this award, the PI published 6 papers, another paper has been accepted for publication, and 5 more papers have been submitted for publication. Further, the PI mentored 4 REU students, gave several international talks, and produced a list of open problems which he maintains on his website. These efforts have been concerned with a wide range of topics in the study of curves and surfaces in Euclidean space, and the major findings were as follows.

In the area of the polyhedral or discrete geometry, the PI obtained both positive and negative results concerning the well-known conjecture of Durer on unfoldability of convex polyhedra. On the one hand the PI proved that all polyhedra become unfoldable after an affine transformation, so there exits no combinatorial obstruction to unfoldability, which answered a question of Croft, Falconer, and Guy. On the other hand, in joint work with one of his REU students, Nicholas Barvinok, the PI produced an example of a convex polyhedron which does not admit a pseudo-edge unfolding, which shows that the conjecture is not true in a purely intrinsic sense.

In the area of classical differential geometry, the PI obtained a deep generalization of the classical 4-vertex theorem to points of vanishing torsion, or vertices, of space curves, which answered a question of Harold Rosenberg related to a problem of Yau: all closed curves in Euclidean space which bound a compact simply connected locally convex surface must have at least 4 vertices. This result is related to the uniqueness problem for isomeyric embedding of closed surfaces. Further, the PI obtained another 4 vertex theorem for star-shaped space curves. Both of these results generalize a theorem of Sedykh on convex space curves.

In joint work with Changwei Xiong, the PI showed that any compact immersed nonnegatively curved hypersurface with free boundary on the sphere is an embedded convex topological disk. As in several other of PI's works, this paper belongs to the intersection of convexity theory with Differential Geometry, and extends classical results on nonnegatively curved hypersurfaces which go back to Hadamard, Chern, do Carmo, and Sacksteder. This work utilizes a combination of old and new techniques.

Another result, which lies in the intersection of convexity theory with Riemannian Geometry, was the paper of PI with Igor Belegradek, where we prove the existence of a continuous selection of points from the interior of disks in Riemannian manifolds. Thus we generalize the notion of center of mass of convex bodies to more complicated regions in a variety of ambient spaces.

In the area of optimization, the PI studied a number of conjectures of Zalgaller on space curves with prescribed width and inradius, via a comination of topological and integral geometric techniques. These estimates confirmed some of these conjectures to within 99% of their stated values and disproved one of them. In particular, estimates where obtained for the length of a closed space curve which contains the sphere in its convex hull, or the shortest orbit which would allow a satelite to probe the entire surface of a planet.

Other optimization problems for space curves, involving generalized notions of area, were investigated in joint work with Ralph Howard, where we obtained some sharp inequalities which extended the classical isoperimetric inequality to space curves. Another work with Ralph Howard was also concerned with regularity of real algebraic surfaces.

The PI's efforts, as summarized above, demonstrate that the study of curves and surfaces in Euclidean space remains a vibrant source of activity and inspiration for the advancement of geometry and related fields, ranging from partial differential equations to real algebraic geometry, with various applications in optimization, convexity theory, and origami engineering. Many of these problems arise from exceedingly simple and natural questions concerning the shape, length, or area of various geometric objects, and prompt the development mathematical tools which may be applied to solve other problems in mathematics and physics.
